253246.text:
**Head's Heroics Power Australia to 5-Wicket Triumph**

Travis Head’s blistering 163 in the first innings set the tone as Australia outmuscled England to clinch a 5-wicket victory. England’s Joe Root (160) and Jacob Bethell (154) fought valiantly across their two innings, totaling 384 and 342, but Australia’s mammoth 567, bolstered by Steve Smith’s 138, built an unassailable lead. Chasing 161 in the fourth innings, Head (29) and Marnus Labuschagne (37) steered the ship, despite Josh Tongue’s fiery 3/42. The finish was clinical—16 runs in the last four overs sealed the deal with minimal fuss.

263546.text:
**Dwarshuis, Davies dismantle Stars as Sixers cruise to six-wicket win**  

Sydney Sixers chased down 129 with clinical precision, courtesy of a disciplined bowling display led by Ben Dwarshuis (4/13) and Joel Davies (2/15). Melbourne Stars stumbled to 128 despite promising starts from Stoinis and Macdonald, undone by regular strikes. Josh Philippe’s brisk 35 ensured the chase rarely felt in doubt, with Marcus Stoinis’ late burst (2/20) and Peter Siddle’s miserly final over (2 runs) proving futile. A 14-run 17th over off Stoinis sealed the deal for the Sixers, who remain a model of efficiency.

263551.text:
**Nathan Ellis and Hurricanes snuff out Strikers with clinical win**  

Hobart Hurricanes defended 178 with aplomb, toppling the Adelaide Strikers by 37 runs in a game dominated by Nathan Ellis' nerveless spell of 2/7 from two overs. The Strikers' chase never gained traction after a disastrous PowerPlay (3/4 in 3 overs), despite Liam Scott's valiant 91 off 58. Rishad Hossain (3/26) and Riley Meredith (2/16) dismantled the middle order, leaving Scott stranded. Earlier, Mitchell Owen's whirlwind 33 off 9 was pivotal in taking the Hurricanes to 178/6. A tame finish from the Strikers sealed a comprehensive win for Hobart.

263555.text:
**Khawaja's Blitz Powers Brisbane Heat to Crushing Win**

Usman Khawaja’s scintillating 78 off 48 balls steered Brisbane Heat to a commanding 7-wicket victory over Sydney Thunder, chasing down 180 with 22 balls to spare. Thunder’s David Warner (82 off 56) set a competitive tone, but Heat’s reply was ruthless—Matt Renshaw (42 off 26) and Jack Wildermuth (39 off 15) piling on the pain. A monstrous 23-run over off David Willey in the 14th sealed the deal, as Heat cruised home in just 16.2 overs. Khawaja, deservedly, walked away as Player of the Match.

263558.text:
**Stars Shine Bright in 8-Wicket Rout of Renegades**

Melbourne Stars demolished Melbourne Renegades by 8 wickets in a one-sided BBL clash, powered by Sam Harper’s blistering 84 off 51. Renegades posted a middling 166/7, with Josh Brown’s 80 off 50 the lone highlight against Marcus Stoinis’ sharp 3/33. Stars, however, were ruthless in reply, cruising to 170/2 in just 15.5 overs. Harper and Thomas Rogers (53 off 24) tore into the bowling, with big overs like the 19-run sixth setting the tone. The last five overs were a mere formality, piling on 52 runs without a hiccup.

263560.text:
**Rain Robs Sydney of Smith’s Show in Sixers-Hurricanes Washout**

The Sydney Sixers were cruising at 32/0 in 5 overs, with Steve Smith cracking 19 off 16 and Babar Azam chipping in with 9 off 14, when the heavens opened against Hobart Hurricanes. With Billy Stanlake (0/9) and Riley Meredith (0/14) unable to dent the top order, the Sixers looked poised for a big total. But nature had other plans, leaving fans frustrated and the match abandoned. No Player of the Match, no drama, just a soggy anticlimax at the SCG.

263564.text:
**Marsh's Blistering 88 Powers Scorchers to 32-Run Triumph**

Mitchell Marsh turned Adelaide Oval into his personal playground, smashing 88 off 51 to propel Perth Scorchers to a towering 232/4. Josh Inglis (42) and Finn Allen (38) provided the fireworks, while Adelaide Strikers’ bowlers bled runs. In reply, Alex Carey (71) and Matthew Short (52) fought valiantly, but the target proved a bridge too far. David Payne (3/35) and Mahli Beardman (2/43) ripped through the middle order, with overs 16 and 17 yielding just 10 runs and 4 wickets. Strikers crumbled to 200/8, despite a late 15-run flurry in the final over. Marsh, deservedly, was Player of the Match.

263568.text:
**Thunder Storm Past Renegades in DLS Thriller**

Sydney Thunder clinched a 4-wicket victory over Melbourne Renegades via the DLS method, with Chris Green’s blistering 34 off 13 earning him Player of the Match honors. Renegades posted 170/8, powered by Hassan Khan’s 46, but Thunder’s bowlers, led by Wes Agar (2/23), kept it in check. Chasing a revised target, Thunder stumbled to 140/6 in 15.2 overs, with Gurinder Sandhu’s 4/42 causing havoc. Yet, a fiery 18-run 14th over and 15-run 15th over turned the tide, sealing a dramatic finish for Green and co.

263575.text:
**Stars Shine Bright in Curran’s Carnage**

Melbourne Stars dismantled Adelaide Strikers by 6 wickets in a one-sided thrashing, powered by Tom Curran’s vicious 4/10 that skittled the Strikers for a measly 83. Mitchell Swepson’s 3/22 and Marcus Stoinis’ 2/8 added salt to the wounds as Cameron Boyce’s 20 was the only flicker of resistance. Chasing, Thomas Rogers’ steady 32 guided Stars home in 15.1 overs, with Stoinis chipping in 23. The finish was a stroll—9 off the 12th, 8 off the 13th—sealing a clinical rout. Curran, deservedly, was Player of the Match.

263579.text:
**Heat Edge Hurricanes in Three-Run Thriller**

Brisbane Heat snatched a nerve-shredding 3-run victory over Hobart Hurricanes in a BBL cliffhanger. Heat posted 160/8, with Nathan McSweeney’s 49 off 32 and Matt Renshaw’s 37 off 25 setting the tone. Hurricanes’ chase, powered by Ben McDermott’s 59 and Beau Webster’s 51, looked on course until the death overs imploded. Matthew Kuhnemann (2/24), the Player of the Match, and Xavier Bartlett (3/44) turned the screws, with just 2 runs off the final over sealing Heat’s win in a dramatic choke by Hurricanes.

263582.text:
**Finn Allen’s Brutal Ton Powers Scorchers to 50-Run Rout**

Finn Allen’s blistering 101 off 53 balls set the tone for Perth Scorchers’ commanding 219/7, with Aaron Hardie and Laurie Evans chipping in quickfire cameos. Melbourne Renegades, despite Tim Seifert’s valiant 66 and Jake Fraser-McGurk’s explosive 42, crumbled to 169/7. Scorchers’ bowlers, led by Cooper Connolly’s miserly 2/23, kept the lid on. The final overs were a mere formality—Renegades limped through with 36 runs across the last five, never threatening a comeback. Allen’s carnage was the undisputed game-changer.

263584.text:
**Smith's Savage Century Sinks Thunder in Sydney Derby**

Steve Smith turned the SCG into his personal playground, blasting a 42-ball 100 to steer Sydney Sixers to a 5-wicket thrashing of Sydney Thunder, chasing down 189 with 16 balls to spare. Thunder’s David Warner had earlier set the tone with a fiery 110 off 65, but Sam Curran’s 3/28 kept them to 189/6. Sixers’ chase wobbled late with three wickets falling between overs 14-16, but Smith’s unbeaten carnage, including a 15-run 17th over off Maddinson, sealed the deal. Babar Azam’s steady 47 played second fiddle to a masterclass.

263587.text:
**Shamsi's Magic Spins Strikers to Crushing Win**

Tabraiz Shamsi turned the screws with a mesmerizing 4/15, skittling Melbourne Renegades for a paltry 99 in 16.5 overs, as Adelaide Strikers romped to an 8-wicket victory. Will Sutherland’s gritty 38 was the only resistance for Renegades. In reply, Strikers cruised home in just 11.5 overs, powered by Matthew Short’s brisk 30. A explosive 17-run 11th over off Brendan Doggett sealed the deal with ease. Shamsi, rightly Player of the Match, proved too hot to handle on a day of spin dominance.

263592.text:
**Scorchers Blaze Past Stars with Allen’s Firepower**

Perth Scorchers dismantled Melbourne Stars by 6 wickets in a clinical chase at home, powered by Finn Allen’s blistering 69 off 39. Stars crumbled to 130 all out, with Marcus Stoinis’ gritty 55 a lone stand against Jhye Richardson’s devastating 4/16. Scorchers’ reply was ruthless—Allen and Aaron Hardie (41 off 37) ensured no hiccups. The final overs were a cruise, with 13 and 12-run bursts in overs 13 and 14 sealing the deal by the 17th. Richardson, deservedly, was Player of the Match.

263597.text:
**Sixers Snatch Victory in Thrilling Finish Against Heat**

Sydney Sixers clinched a 5-wicket win over Brisbane Heat, chasing down 171 with 8 balls to spare. Nathan McSweeney’s gritty 69 anchored Heat’s 171/9, despite Mitchell Starc’s fiery 4/35. In reply, Steve Smith’s composed 54 set the tone for Sixers, but it was Sam Curran’s explosive 53 off 27—earning him Player of the Match—that turned the tide. The finish was electric: a massive 17-run 18th over off Matthew Kuhnemann and 16 in the 19th sealed the deal, even as Heat’s Xavier Bartlett fought back with late wickets. Pure T20 chaos!

263600.text:
**Scorchers Torch Sixers in 48-Run Rout**

Perth Scorchers dismantled Sydney Sixers by 48 runs in a one-sided thrashing, powered by Finn Allen’s blistering 49 off 30. Scorchers stumbled to 147/9, with Ashton Turner’s 29 offering grit, while Mitchell Starc (2/32) kept Sixers in the hunt. But the chase imploded to 99 all out in 15 overs, despite Steve Smith’s fighting 37. Mahli Beardman (3/20) and David Payne (2/13) ripped through the middle order, with the last five overs yielding just 33 runs and 5 wickets. Sixers, simply scorched.

263604.text:
**Hurricanes Edge Stars in DLS Nail-Biter**

Hobart Hurricanes snatched a dramatic 3-run victory over Melbourne Stars via the DLS method in a rain-hit clash. Beau Webster’s blistering 47 off 26 powered Hurricanes to 114/5 in 10 overs, with Nikhil Chaudhary’s quickfire 24 adding punch. Stars, chasing a revised target, faltered at 81/4 in 7 overs despite Joe Clarke’s 31. The finish was electric—22 runs off Mitchell Owen’s 7th over kept Stars alive, but Riley Meredith’s tight 2/19 sealed it for Hurricanes. Webster, deservedly, took Player of the Match.

263608.text:
**Sixers Smash Hurricanes with 57-Run Rout**

Sydney Sixers demolished Hobart Hurricanes by 57 runs in a one-sided thrashing at the SCG. Steve Smith’s classy 65 off 43 anchored Sixers to a formidable 198/8, with late fireworks from Joel Davies (27 off 12) and Lachlan Shaw (21 off 13). Hurricanes’ chase crumbled to 141 all out in 17.2 overs, despite Ben McDermott’s fighting 40. Ben Dwarshuis (3/26) and Sean Abbott (2/18) ripped through the middle order, while Mitchell Starc’s tight spells sealed the deal. The final overs? A mere formality—Hurricanes lost 6 wickets for just 43 runs. Ouch.

263610.text:
**Perth Scorchers cruise past Sixers in clinical chase**

Perth Scorchers made light work of Sydney Sixers, chasing down 133 with 6 wickets and 15 balls to spare. Sixers crumbled to 132 all out, with Steve Smith, Josh Philippe, and Moises Henriques each managing just 24, as Jhye Richardson (3/32) and David Payne (3/18) tore through them. In reply, Mitchell Marsh’s steady 44, backed by Finn Allen’s brisk 36, sealed the deal. The chase tightened briefly with wickets in overs 16 and 17, but a breezy 9-run 18th over ensured Scorchers’ dominance.

263999.text:
**Kohli's Grit Guides India to Tense 4-Wicket Win**

India hunted down New Zealand’s 300/8 with a nervy 4-wicket victory, finishing at 306/6 in 49 overs. Daryl Mitchell’s 84 and Henry Nicholls’ 62 set a challenging total, despite Mohammed Siraj’s tidy 2/40. In reply, Virat Kohli’s steely 93 anchored India’s chase, with Shubman Gill (56) and Shreyas Iyer (49) chipping in. Kyle Jamieson’s fiery 4/41 kept the pressure on, but a massive 17-run 49th over off Kristian Clarke sealed the deal. India’s late surge in the final overs—49 runs in five—proved decisive.

264000.text:
**Mitchell's Masterclass Sinks India in Thriller**

Daryl Mitchell’s blazing 131 off 117 balls powered New Zealand to a commanding 7-wicket win over India, chasing down 284 with 15 balls to spare. KL Rahul’s gritty 112 had given India a fighting total of 284/7, with Shubman Gill’s 56 providing early momentum. But Mitchell, alongside Will Young’s composed 87, dismantled India’s attack. The finish was clinical—NZ cruised with 42 runs in the last five overs, including a punishing 11-run 47th over off Prasidh Krishna. India’s bowlers, led by Harshit Rana, had no answers.

264001.text:
**Mitchell's Masterclass Powers New Zealand to 41-Run Triumph**

Daryl Mitchell’s blistering 137, backed by Glenn Phillips’ explosive 106, propelled New Zealand to a daunting 337/8 against India. Arshdeep Singh and Harshit Rana snared three wickets each, but couldn’t stem the tide. In reply, Virat Kohli’s valiant 124 kept India alive, with Nitish Kumar Reddy and Rana chipping in fifties. Yet, the chase unraveled in a chaotic finish—21 runs in the 43rd over raised hopes, but Zakary Foulkes and Kristian Clarke’s late strikes (2 wickets each in overs 44 and 46) sealed India’s fate at 296. Mitchell, deservedly, was Player of the Match.

264002.text:
**Abhishek Sharma's Blitz Powers India to 48-Run Rout of New Zealand**

Abhishek Sharma’s blistering 84 off 35 balls set the tone for India’s commanding 238/7, with Rinku Singh (44 off 20) and Suryakumar Yadav (32 off 22) adding firepower. New Zealand fought back through Glenn Phillips’ valiant 78 off 40, but 190/7 was never enough. India’s bowlers, led by Varun Chakaravarthy (2/37) and Shivam Dube (2/28), kept the pressure on. The finish was a formality—NZ limped through the last five overs, managing just 46 runs while losing two wickets in the final over to seal their fate.

264003.text:
**Suryakumar's Blitz Powers India to 7-Wicket Rout of New Zealand**

India demolished New Zealand by 7 wickets in a T20 masterclass, chasing down 209 in just 15.2 overs. Suryakumar Yadav’s explosive 82 off 37 and Ishan Kishan’s fiery 76 off 32 made a mockery of the Kiwi attack, with Shivam Dube’s 36 off 18 adding the finishing punch. Earlier, Mitchell Santner (47) and Rachin Ravindra (44) lifted New Zealand to 208/6, but Kuldeep Yadav’s 2/35 kept them in check. The final overs were a cakewalk—18 off the 14th sealed India’s dominance.

264004.text:
**India demolish New Zealand in 10-over blitz**

India obliterated New Zealand by 8 wickets in a T20 thrashing, chasing down 153 in just 10 overs. New Zealand’s innings limped to 153/9, with Glenn Phillips’ 48 the only resistance against Jasprit Bumrah’s lethal 3/17 and Ravi Bishnoi’s crafty 2/18. India’s reply was a carnage—Abhishek Sharma’s explosive 68 off 20 and Suryakumar Yadav’s silky 57 off 26 sealed the deal. The final five overs were a run-fest, with 83 runs plundered, including a monstrous 22-run over off Jacob Duffy in the sixth. Utter domination.

264005.text:
**New Zealand Stun India with 50-Run Thrashing**

New Zealand outclassed India, clinching a 50-run victory in a T20 showdown. Batting first, the Kiwis posted 215/7, powered by Tim Seifert’s blistering 62 off 36 and Devon Conway’s 44 off 23. India’s chase faltered despite Shivam Dube’s explosive 65 off 23, crumbling to 165 all out in 18.4 overs. Mitchell Santner’s 3/26 dismantled the middle order, while Ish Sodhi’s double-wicket over 17 (5 runs, 2 wickets) sealed the collapse. A late slump—just 10 runs and 5 wickets in the last four overs—left India shell-shocked.

264006.text:
**Kishan’s Blitz Powers India to 46-Run Rout Over New Zealand**

Ishan Kishan’s savage 103 off 43 balls set the tone as India smashed 271/5, with Suryakumar Yadav (63 off 30) and Hardik Pandya (42 off 17) piling on the pain. New Zealand’s reply had fire with Finn Allen’s 80 off 38, but Arshdeep Singh’s 5/51, backed by Axar Patel’s 3/33, snuffed out hope. The finish wasn’t close—NZ crumbled, losing 4 wickets in the last 5 overs despite late sparks (14 runs in the 19th). Kishan, deservedly, walked away as Player of the Match.

266205.text:
**Sri Lanka Edge England in Tense 19-Run Triumph**

Sri Lanka clinched a gritty 19-run victory over England, powered by Kusal Mendis’ classy 93 and a late bowling blitz. Posting 271/6, Sri Lanka’s total looked challenging, with Janith Liyanage (46) providing muscle. England’s reply hinged on Ben Duckett (62) and Joe Root (61), but Dunith Wellalage (2/41) and Pramod Madushan (3/39) turned the screws. The finish was electric—Madushan’s double-wicket 46th over (10 runs) and a nervy 49th (14 runs) kept England at bay, falling short at 252. Wellalage, deservedly, was Player of the Match.

266206.text:
**Root's Masterclass Powers England to 5-Wicket Triumph**

Joe Root’s sublime 75 steered England to a clinical 5-wicket victory over Sri Lanka, chasing down 219 with grit and flair. Sri Lanka’s innings crumbled at 219, with Charith Asalanka (45) and Dhananjaya de Silva (40) offering resistance against Jamie Overton (2/21) and Root’s surprise 2/13. England’s reply was anchored by Root, with Harry Brook (42) and Ben Duckett (39) chipping in. The finish was smooth—12 runs in the 46th over off Pavan Rathnayake sealed the deal, as England cruised home in 46.2 overs. Root, deservedly, was Player of the Match.

266207.text:
**Brook's Blitz Powers England to 53-Run Triumph Over Sri Lanka**

Harry Brook’s savage 136 off just 66 balls, backed by Joe Root’s classy 111, propelled England to a towering 357/3. Sri Lanka’s bowlers, led by Hasaranga and Vandersay, bled runs. In reply, Pavan Rathnayake’s gutsy 121 and Pathum Nissanka’s brisk 50 gave hope, but 304 was never enough. England’s bowlers, with Liam Dawson and Will Jacks snaring two each, tightened the screws. The finish fizzled—Sri Lanka limped through the last five overs, managing just 33 runs while losing two wickets. England, ruthless.

266208.text:
**England edge Sri Lanka in rain-hit thriller**

England clinched an 11-run victory over Sri Lanka via the DLS method in a rain-interrupted clash, with Adil Rashid’s magical 3/19 earning him Player of the Match. Sri Lanka crumbled to 133, despite Kusal Mendis’ brisk 37, as Rashid and Sam Curran (3/38) ran riot. In reply, Phil Salt’s composed 46 steered England to 125/4 in 15 overs, even as the chase tightened in the final stretch with just 32 runs across the last five overs. A nervy finish, but England held their cool.

266209.text:
**Banton Blitz Powers England to DLS Triumph Over Sri Lanka**

England chased down a rain-adjusted 173/4 to beat Sri Lanka by 6 wickets, with Tom Banton’s swashbuckling 54 off 33 earning him Player of the Match. Sri Lanka’s 189/5 was built on Pavan Rathnayake’s brisk 40, but Jofra Archer’s 2/42 kept them in check. England’s reply roared through Banton and Jos Buttler (39), while Harry Brook’s 36 off 12 sealed the deal. The finish was a cruise—17 off Hasaranga in the 14th turned the tide, and steady scoring in the last overs buried Sri Lanka’s hopes.

266210.text:
**England Edge Sri Lanka in Tense 12-Run Thriller**

England scraped past Sri Lanka by 12 runs in a low-scoring T20 clash that went down to the wire. Sam Curran’s gritty 58 anchored England’s modest 128/9, with Dushmantha Chameera’s fiery 5/24 tearing through their lineup. Sri Lanka’s chase faltered despite Kusal Mendis’ 26, crumbling to 116 all out in 19.3 overs. Jacob Bethell’s sensational 4/11, including a devastating 18th over with 3 wickets for 5 runs, sealed the deal, while Will Jacks’ 3/14 added the early sting. A nail-biter till the last ball!

266897.text:
**South Africa demolish West Indies in 9-wicket rout**

South Africa made mincemeat of West Indies, cruising to a 9-wicket victory in a lopsided T20 clash. West Indies limped to 173/7, with Shimron Hetmyer’s 48 the only spark in a stuttering innings, as George Linde’s fiery 3/25 tore through their middle order. In reply, Aiden Markram’s blistering 86 off 47 balls led a ruthless chase, supported by Lhuan-dre Pretorius (44) and Ryan Rickelton (40). The Proteas sealed it with 14 balls to spare, a 14-run 15th over off Jayden Seales burying any faint Windies hopes.

266898.text:
**De Kock's Brutal Ton Powers South Africa to 7-Wicket Rout**

Quinton de Kock’s savage 115 off 49 balls obliterated West Indies as South Africa chased down 221 with 15 balls to spare, winning by 7 wickets. Ryan Rickelton’s 77 off 36 added fuel to the fire, while West Indies’ Shimron Hetmyer (75) and Sherfane Rutherford (57) had earlier set a competitive total. The finish was a mere formality—South Africa plundered 19 in the 16th over off Romario Shepherd, sealing the deal with ease. West Indies’ bowlers, led by Akeal Hosein (2/41), couldn’t stem the tide.

266899.text:
**West Indies edge South Africa in thrilling DLS finish**

West Indies clinched a nail-biting 6-run victory over South Africa via the DLS method in a rain-hit clash. Shai Hope (48 off 25) and Shimron Hetmyer (48 off 22) powered West Indies to 114/3 in 10 overs, while Gudakesh Motie’s 3/17 derailed South Africa’s chase, leaving them at 118/6. The finish was electric—South Africa smashed 21 in the 8th over, but Motie’s double-wicket 6th and Shamar Joseph’s clutch final over (9 runs, 1 wicket) sealed the deal for the Caribbean side. Pure drama!

267686.text:
**De Klerk’s all-round brilliance sinks Mumbai in last-over thriller**  

Royal Challengers Bengaluru clinched a nerve-jangling 3-wicket win over Mumbai Indians, powered by Nadine De Klerk’s all-round heroics. Chasing 155, RCB stumbled to 137/7 after Nicola Carey’s double strike in the 17th over, but De Klerk (63* off 44) held her nerve. With 20 needed off the final over, Nat Sciver-Brunt crumbled under pressure, conceding two boundaries and a six as De Klerk sealed it with a flourish. Earlier, De Klerk’s 4/26 had stifled MI, despite Sajana Sajeevan’s brisk 45 and Nicola Carey’s 40. RCB's lower order wobbled but their MVP stood tall.

267687.text:
**Giants Edge Warriorz in Nail-Biting 10-Run Finish**

Gujarat Giants clinched a thrilling 10-run victory over UP Warriorz, posting a formidable 207/4 led by Ashleigh Gardner’s blistering 65 off 41. Sophie Devine (38 off 20) and Anushka Sharma (44 off 30) kept the scoreboard ticking. In reply, Phoebe Litchfield’s valiant 78 off 40 wasn’t enough as Warriorz finished at 197/8. The final overs swung wildly—16 off the last over by Devine couldn’t salvage it. Georgia Wareham’s composed 2/30, including a tight 17th over, earned her Player of the Match honors.

267688.text:
**Mumbai Indians Crush Delhi Capitals in 50-Run Rout**

Mumbai Indians flexed their muscle, hammering Delhi Capitals by 50 runs in a one-sided thrashing. Harmanpreet Kaur (74 off 42) and Nat Sciver-Brunt (70 off 46) powered MI to a towering 195/4, leaving DC shell-shocked. In reply, Chinelle Henry’s gritty 56 off 33 was a lone spark in a dismal 145 all out. Nicola Carey (3/37) and Amelia Kerr (3/24) tore through DC’s lineup, with the final overs turning into a procession—Over 18’s double-wicket blow (3 runs, 2 scalps) sealing the inevitable. Mumbai simply unstoppable.

267727.text:
**Afghanistan Outmuscle West Indies in 38-Run Rout**

Afghanistan powered to a commanding 38-run victory over West Indies, thanks to a blistering 181/3 led by Ibrahim Zadran’s 87 and Darwish Rasooli’s match-defining 84. West Indies crumbled to 143/9 in reply, with Quentin Sampson’s 30 a lone flicker of resistance. Ziaur Rahman (3/36) and Rashid Khan (2/19) tore through the lineup, while the final overs saw drama with Noor Ahmad’s double-wicket 18th over (14 runs) sealing the deal. West Indies needed a miracle, but Afghanistan’s death bowling—capped by Ziaur’s last-ball wicket—ensured none came.

267728.text:
**Mujeeb magic floors West Indies in Kabul clash**  

Afghanistan outclassed West Indies by 39 runs, powered by a solid top-order effort and a spin choke from Mujeeb Ur Rahman (4/21). Darwish Rasooli's fluent 68 and Sediqullah Atal's steady 53 anchored Afghanistan to 189/4.  

In response, the Windies stumbled to 150 all out despite Brandon King's 50 and a blistering 46 off 17 from Shimron Hetmyer. The chase unraveled in a chaotic final phase as Mujeeb and Rashid Khan spun webs, with 5 wickets tumbling in the last 4 overs. Azmatullah Omarzai chipped in all-round brilliance, sealing an emphatic Afghan win.

267729.text:
**Springer’s Late Blitz Sinks Afghanistan**

West Indies clinched a nervy 13-run victory over Afghanistan, defending 151/7 thanks to Shamar Springer’s heroics with 4/20. Brandon King’s 47 set the tone for West Indies, while Rashid Khan’s miserly 2/13 kept Afghanistan in the hunt. Chasing, Rahmanullah Gurbaz’s gritty 73 gave hope, but the wheels fell off in the death overs. Springer’s devastating 19th over, snaring 3 wickets for just 5 runs, crushed Afghanistan’s spirit, leaving them stranded at 138/8. A clinical finish from a side that refused to buckle.

268159.text:
**Sri Lanka edge Pakistan in 14-run thriller**

Sri Lanka clinched a gritty 14-run victory over Pakistan in a pulsating 12-over clash, defending 160/6 with ice in their veins. Dasun Shanaka’s blistering 34 off 9 and Kusal Mendis’ 30 off 16 set the tone, while Wanindu Hasaranga’s 4/35 dismantled Pakistan’s chase of 146/8. The finish was a rollercoaster—Hasaranga’s double-wicket 10th over (15 runs, 2 scalps) and Matheesha Pathirana’s tight 11th (10 runs, 1 wicket) squeezed Pakistan, despite Salman Agha’s valiant 45 off 12. Sri Lanka held firm when it mattered most.

268168.text:
**Giants Edge Capitals in Heart-Stopping 4-Run Thriller**

Gujarat Giants clinched a nail-biting 4-run victory over Delhi Capitals, defending 209 in a rollercoaster finish. Sophie Devine’s blistering 95 off 42 and Ashleigh Gardner’s 49 powered Giants to a daunting total, despite Nandni Sharma’s fiery 5/33. In response, Lizelle Lee (86) and Laura Wolvaardt (77) kept Capitals in the hunt, smashing 22 in the 19th over off Kashvee Gautam. But Devine’s nervy final over, conceding just 2 runs and snaring 2 wickets, sealed the deal in a dramatic collapse. Pure chaos!

268169.text:
**RCB Crush UP Warriorz in 9-Wicket Demolition**

Royal Challengers Bengaluru made a mockery of UP Warriorz’s 143/5, storming to 145/1 in just 12.1 overs. Grace Harris’s blistering 85 off 40 balls was a masterclass, with Smriti Mandhana’s steady 47 off 32 providing the perfect foil. Earlier, Deepti Sharma (45) and Deandra Dottin (40) fought hard for Warriorz, but Shreyanka Patil (2/50) and Nadine De Klerk (2/28) kept them in check. The finish was a breeze—RCB plundered 41 runs in the last four overs, sealing a ruthless victory.

268170.text:
**Mumbai Indians cruise past Gujarat Giants in style**

Mumbai Indians made light work of Gujarat Giants, chasing down 193 with 7 wickets and 4 balls to spare. Harmanpreet Kaur’s blistering 71 off 43 led the charge, with Amanjot Kaur (40) and Nicola Carey (38) providing the firepower. Earlier, Gujarat’s 192/5 was built on Georgia Wareham’s steady 43 and Bharti Fulmali’s quickfire 36. The finish was a formality—Mumbai smashed 20 off the 16th and 16 off the 18th, coasting home without breaking a sweat. Giants’ bowlers had no answers.

268171.text:
**Delhi Capitals Cruise to 7-Wicket Win Over UP Warriorz**

Delhi Capitals made light work of UP Warriorz’s 154/8, chasing it down with 158/3 in 20 overs, powered by Lizelle Lee’s blistering 67 off 44 and Shafali Verma’s dual heroics—36 off 32 with the bat and 2/16 with the ball, earning her Player of the Match. Despite Deepti Sharma’s late double strike (2/26), Delhi’s finish was clinical, with 43 runs in the last five overs, including a breezy 13 off Sophie Ecclestone in the 16th. UP’s Meg Lanning (54) fought hard, but it wasn’t enough.

268172.text:
**UP Warriorz outmuscle Mumbai Indians in 7-wicket romp**

UP Warriorz chased down Mumbai Indians’ 161/5 with swagger, sealing a 7-wicket win in just 18.1 overs. Nat Sciver-Brunt’s gritty 65 (43) had propped up MI, but Warriorz’s Harleen Deol (64 off 39) and Chloe Tryon’s blistering 27 (11) turned the tide. The finish was a breeze, with a massive 22-run 16th over off Sanskriti Gupta breaking MI’s spirit, followed by steady strikes to close out. Sciver-Brunt’s 2/28 couldn’t stem the flow—Warriorz were just too good on the night.

268173.text:
**RCB's Shreyanka Spins Gujarat Giants into Oblivion**

Royal Challengers Bengaluru clinched a commanding 32-run victory over Gujarat Giants, posting 182/7 with Radha Yadav’s gritty 66 and Richa Ghosh’s explosive 44. Gujarat’s chase faltered at 150, despite Bharti Fulmali’s fiery 39. Shreyanka Patil was the wrecker-in-chief, snaring 5/23, including two scalps in a miserly 19th over conceding just 2 runs. Lauren Bell’s double-wicket 17th over (6 runs) tightened the noose, ensuring Gujarat’s collapse in 18.5 overs. RCB’s bowlers turned the screws late, leaving Giants gasping in the final stretch.

268174.text:
**Lanning's Blinder Powers UP Warriorz to 22-Run Triumph**

Meg Lanning’s ferocious 70 off 45, paired with Phoebe Litchfield’s classy 61, propelled UP Warriorz to a daunting 187/8 against Mumbai Indians. Mumbai’s chase faltered despite Amelia Kerr’s valiant 49, ending at 165/6. The final five overs saw Warriorz tighten the screws—Shikha Pandey’s miserly 19th over (3 runs, 1 wicket) snuffed out any lingering hope after Mumbai plundered 40 runs in the preceding three. Lanning, deservedly Player of the Match, was the difference in a clash that Warriorz dominated from ball one.

268175.text:
**Mandhana's Magic Powers RCB to 8-Wicket Rout of Delhi Capitals**

Smriti Mandhana’s blistering 96 off 61 balls was the heartbeat of Royal Challengers Bengaluru’s dominant 8-wicket win over Delhi Capitals. Chasing 167, RCB cruised home in 18.2 overs, with Georgia Voll’s steady 54 off 42 playing perfect foil. Earlier, DC stumbled to 166 all out, despite Shafali Verma’s fiery 62 off 41, as Lauren Bell (3/26) and Sayali Satghare (3/27) ripped through their lineup. The finish was a formality—RCB plundered 42 runs in the last five overs, sealing it with disdain.

268176.text:
**RCB Crush Gujarat Giants with 61-Run Demolition**

Royal Challengers Bengaluru flexed their muscle, hammering Gujarat Giants by 61 runs in a one-sided thrashing. Gautami Naik’s blistering 73 off 55 set the tone for RCB’s 178/6, with Smriti Mandhana and Richa Ghosh chipping in handy cameos. Gujarat’s chase never ignited, crumbling to 117/8 despite Ashleigh Gardner’s gritty 54. Sayali Satghare’s 3/21 tore through their middle order, while the final overs fizzled out with just 32 runs across the last five. RCB cruised, leaving Giants in the dust.

268177.text:
**Jemimah’s Cool Head Guides Delhi Capitals to 7-Wicket Triumph**

Delhi Capitals cruised past Mumbai Indians by 7 wickets, with Jemimah Rodrigues’ composed 51 off 37 earning her Player of the Match honors. Mumbai’s 154/5, powered by Nat Sciver-Brunt’s 65 and Harmanpreet Kaur’s 41, seemed competitive, but Delhi’s chase was clinical. Lizelle Lee’s fiery 46 off 28 and Shafali Verma’s brisk 29 set the tone. The final overs were a breeze—14 off the 19th from Sciver-Brunt sealed it with an over to spare. Mumbai’s bowlers, despite Amanjot Kaur’s thrift, couldn’t stem the tide.

268178.text:
**Devine's All-Round Heroics Crush UP Warriorz**

Gujarat Giants stormed to a 45-run victory over UP Warriorz, powered by Sophie Devine's dual brilliance. Devine’s 50 off 42 anchored Giants to 153/8, with Beth Mooney’s 38 adding grit. Warriorz crumbled to 108 all out in 17.3 overs, despite Phoebe Litchfield’s 32. Rajeshwari Gayakwad’s 3/16 and Devine’s 2/16 in the death overs choked the chase, with just 28 runs and 4 wickets in the last five. Warriorz never stood a chance as Giants tightened the screws with ruthless precision.

268179.text:
**Delhi Capitals cruise past RCB with 7-wicket triumph**

Delhi Capitals made light work of Royal Challengers Bengaluru, chasing down 109 with 7 wickets and 26 balls to spare. RCB’s Smriti Mandhana battled with 38, but Nandni Sharma (3/26) and Marizanne Kapp (2/17) triggered a collapse to 109 all out. In reply, Laura Wolvaardt’s composed 42 guided DC, with Jemimah Rodrigues (24) playing a steady hand. The finish was a formality—12 runs in the 15th over off Georgia Voll sealed it. DC never broke a sweat, leaving RCB to ponder their batting frailties.

268180.text:
**Nat Sciver-Brunt’s ton powers Mumbai past RCB in a high-scoring thriller**  

Nat Sciver-Brunt’s scintillating 100 off 57 balls set the stage for Mumbai Indians’ 15-run victory over Royal Challengers Bengaluru. Chasing 200, RCB wobbled early but Richa Ghosh kept them alive with a blistering 90 off 50. However, Hayley Matthews’ golden arm (3/10) and Shabnim Ismail’s sharp spells (2/25) ensured Mumbai stayed on top. The drama peaked in the 19th over when Amanjot Kaur leaked 27 runs, briefly reviving RCB’s hopes, but Amelia Kerr’s nerveless final over sealed the deal. Earlier, Matthews’ 56 and Harmanpreet’s cameo complemented Sciver-Brunt’s masterclass in a dominant Mumbai batting effort.

268181.text:
**Gujarat Giants Edge Delhi Capitals in Three-Run Thriller**

Gujarat Giants clinched a nail-biting 3-run victory over Delhi Capitals, defending 174/9 in a rollercoaster finish. Beth Mooney’s classy 58 set the tone for Giants, while Delhi’s Niki Prasad (47) and Sneh Rana (29) fought hard in the chase. The last five overs exploded with drama—23 runs in the 17th and 20 in the 19th kept Capitals alive, but Sophie Devine’s clutch final over (5 runs, 2 wickets) sealed the deal. Giants’ nerves held, just, in a finish that had everyone on edge.

268182.text:
**RCB Crush UP Warriorz in One-Sided Thrashing**

Royal Challengers Bengaluru dismantled UP Warriorz by 8 wickets, chasing down 143 with a staggering 41 balls to spare. Grace Harris (75 off 37) and Smriti Mandhana (54 off 27) unleashed carnage, with big overs like the 20-run third and 15-run twelfth sealing the deal early. UP’s Deepti Sharma (55) and Meg Lanning (41) fought hard, but Nadine De Klerk’s 4/22 crippled their innings. RCB’s ruthless finish, capped by an 8-run 13th over, left Warriorz shell-shocked in a lopsided contest.

268183.text:
**Giants edge past Mumbai in a nervy 11-run heist**

Gujarat Giants clinched a gritty 11-run victory over Mumbai Indians, powered by Georgia Wareham’s all-round heroics. Giants posted a competitive 167/4, with Ashleigh Gardner (46) and Wareham (44) leading the charge. Mumbai’s chase, fueled by Harmanpreet Kaur’s blazing 82, looked on course until the death overs turned chaotic. Wareham’s tight spells (2/26) and Sophie Devine’s composure (2/23) choked the runs, despite a late 14-run burst in the 20th over. Over 17’s 16-run explosion couldn’t save Mumbai, who finished at 156/7. Wareham, deservedly, was Player of the Match.

268184.text:
**Delhi Capitals cruise past UP Warriorz in clinical chase**

Delhi Capitals made light work of UP Warriorz, sealing a 5-wicket victory with 8 balls to spare. Warriorz stumbled to a modest 122/8, with Deepti Sharma’s gritty 24 the best of a shaky lot, as Marizanne Kapp (3/30) tore through them. In reply, Laura Wolvaardt’s composed 47 and Jemimah Rodrigues’ fiery 34 off 18 powered Capitals to 126/5. The chase tightened briefly in the death overs, but a steady 9-run 18th over off Asha Sobhana ensured no late hiccups for Delhi.

268185.text:
**Rodrigues and Lee sizzle as Delhi cruise past Gujarat**  

Delhi Capitals made light work of Gujarat Giants’ 168/7, chasing it down with 26 balls to spare. Lizelle Lee’s blistering 43 off 24 set the tone, while Jemimah Rodrigues (41 off 23) finished things off with her trademark elegance. Gujarat’s bowlers were taken to the cleaners early, with back-to-back big overs in the Powerplay (17 and 21 runs) leaving them gasping. Georgia Wareham’s 2/28 provided a glimmer, but it was too little, too late. Earlier, Beth Mooney’s patient 62 went in vain as Gujarat fell well short of a par score.

268187.text:
**Ireland steamroll UAE with Delany's magic**

Ireland crushed UAE by 57 runs in a one-sided T20 affair, powered by Gareth Delany's match-defining 3/26. Ireland posted a solid 178/6, with Ross Adair (39) and Lorcan Tucker (38) setting the tone. UAE's chase never ignited, crumbling to 121 all out despite Muhammad Waseem’s gritty 40. Delany and Matthew Humphreys (3/26) ripped through the middle order, while Barry McCarthy’s late burst (2/26) sealed the deal. The final overs were a procession—UAE limping with just 25 runs and 7 wickets down in the last five. Brutal.

268188.text:
**Campher’s All-Round Brilliance Powers Ireland to 30-Run Win**

Curtis Campher’s dazzling 54 off 41 set the tone for Ireland’s 170/7, with Mark Adair’s brisk 34 adding punch against a spirited UAE bowling attack led by Muhammad Arfan’s 2/23. Chasing, UAE faltered despite Aryansh Sharma’s gritty 54, finishing at 140/8. Ireland’s bowlers, with George Dockrell’s miserly 2/12, tightened the screws in the death overs. The final five overs saw UAE scrape just 38 runs for 3 wickets, including a desperate 14-run 19th over, but it was too little, too late. Campher, deservedly, was Player of the Match.

268676.text:
**Ireland scrape past Italy in nervy three-wicket thriller**

Ireland stumbled their way to a jittery three-wicket win over Italy, chasing down 119 with just three balls to spare. Italy, bowled out for 118 in 18.1 overs, owed much to Anthony Mosca’s brisk 35, but Matthew Humphreys’ 4 for 16 gutted their middle order. In reply, Harry Tector’s gritty 41 and Lorcan Tucker’s 34 kept Ireland afloat. The finish turned ugly—Grant Stewart’s double-wicket 18th over (1 run, 2 wickets) nearly derailed the chase, but Ireland limped home at 119 for 7 in 19.3. Phew.

268677.text:
**Ireland Hold Nerve to Edge Italy by 24 Runs**

Harry Tector’s blistering 96 off 56 powered Ireland to a formidable 190/5, setting a steep challenge for Italy. In reply, Anthony Mosca (69) and Wayne Madsen (61) kept Italy in the hunt with a spirited stand, but Ireland’s bowlers tightened the screws in the final overs. Despite a late surge with 14 runs in the 19th over off Barry McCarthy, Italy fell short at 166/4. Mark Adair and Gareth Delany’s clutch overs ensured Ireland’s grip never slipped, sealing a hard-fought victory.

268678.text:
**Italy Stuns Ireland in Dramatic Last-Over Heist**

Italy pulled off a jaw-dropping 4-wicket upset over Ireland, chasing down 154 with just three balls to spare. Ireland, bowled out for 154 in 19.4 overs, relied on Paul Stirling’s gritty 45, but Crishan Kalugamage’s 3/28 kept them in check. Italy’s reply hinged on Wayne Madsen’s composed 39 and Grant Stewart’s fiery 33. The finish was pure chaos—18 runs off Barry McCarthy’s final over sealed it after a tense 14-run 19th over from Mark Adair. Italy’s nerve held; Ireland’s didn’t.

269212.text:
**Pakistan edge Australia in thrilling 22-run finish**

Pakistan clinched a gritty 22-run victory over Australia in a pulsating T20 clash, powered by Saim Ayub’s dual brilliance. Ayub’s brisk 40 off 22 anchored Pakistan to 168/8, with Salman Agha’s 39 lending spine, despite Adam Zampa’s lethal 4/24. Australia’s chase faltered at 146/8, even as Cameron Green (36) and Xavier Bartlett (34) fought hard. Ayub (2/29) and Abrar Ahmed (2/10) turned the screws, especially in the tense final overs, where Pakistan held firm, conceding just 35 runs in the last five to seal the deal.

269213.text:
**Pakistan demolish Australia with 90-run thrashing**

Pakistan roared to a commanding 90-run victory over Australia, powered by Salman Agha's blistering 76 off 40 and Usman Khan’s steady 53. Their 198/5 proved a mountain too steep for the Aussies, who crumbled to 108 all out in 15.4 overs. Cameron Green’s 35 was a lone spark in a dismal chase. Shadab Khan (3/26) and Abrar Ahmed (3/14) tore through the batting, with the final overs a mere formality—Australia leaking wickets while scraping just 31 runs in the last five. Utter domination.

269214.text:
**Pakistan Crush Australia with Nawaz's Fiery Five-for**

Pakistan dismantled Australia by 111 runs in a one-sided T20 clash, powered by a ruthless bowling display. Saim Ayub (56) and Babar Azam (50) laid a solid foundation with 207/6, while Shadab Khan’s late 46 off 19 added the punch. Australia’s reply crumbled to 96 all out, with Mohammad Nawaz’s sensational 5/18 in 4 overs breaking their spine. The finish was a formality—Nawaz’s double-wicket over in the 14th (2 runs, 2 wickets) sealed the rout as Australia limped through the last overs, never in the hunt.
